context: Decanal was formed by 45% of “Southern” yeasts, while “Northern” yeasts didn't form this compound. As regards ketones, 2-heptanone and 2-nonanone were recovered in 45% and in 35% of wine samples produced by “Southern” Italy strains, respectively, and in 37.5% and in 25% of wine samples obtained with “Northern” yeasts, respectively (Fig. 1). Other aromatic compounds were determined in low amounts both in wines produced by S. cerevisiae “Southern” and “Northern” yeasts (Table 1). In summary, S. cerevisiae isolated from Southern Italy grapes were able to produce more volatile compounds than those from Northern Italy. Consequently, yeasts from South Italy can produce potentially more complex wines from a specific must. During fermentation all yeasts produced ethanol, 3-methyl-1-butanol, and ethyl acetate. Also, the production of acids during the alcoholic fermentation was a characteristic of “Southern Italy” strains.

The focus is on the volatile compounds produced, such as decanal, ketones, and other aromatic compounds, which are significant in wine complexity. While sulfur dioxide is commonly used in winemaking to preserve volatile compounds, its direct relationship with the volatile substances produced by the yeasts is not detailed in the provided context.
